question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$
inference:
Solution:

Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Then
\[r(x) = (q \circ p)^{-1}(y).\]Since $q$ and $p$ are invertible,
\[p(x) = q^{-1}((q \circ p)^{-1}(y)).\]Then
\[x = p^{-1}(q^{-1}((q \circ p)^{-1}(y))).\]Hence,
\[f^{-1}(y) = p^{-1}(q^{-1}((q \circ p)^{-1}(y))).\]Since $q \circ p$ is invertible,
\[(q \circ p)^{-1} = p^{-1} \circ q^{-1},\]so
\[f^{-1}(y) = p^{-1}(q^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)))) = \boxed{\text{D}}.\]Final Answer: $\boxed{\text{D}}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get
\[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get
\[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get
\[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$

Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get
\[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get
\[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get
\[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
